text: A tense surgery in progress.  Meters flicker, instruments flash in the bright overhead light.  In the midst of it a stands DR. DAVID RAVELL, 35.  The master of his domain. Ravell leans forward so a NURSE can mop the sweat from hi brow as he completes a last, delicate procedure.  His co workers sigh collectively with relief.
(to Asst. Surgeon) Close her up, will you?

Dr. Ravell comes out of surgery, clearly exhausted.  With his surgical mask he is ruggedly handsome.  TWO NURSES follow, attending him like a fighter fresh from the ring: CHLOE, 25, Raven-haired and striking, and JASMINE, 24, an exotic mix of African-American and Asian. BLAKE DANIELS, 58, the silver-haired Chief Surgeon, rushe the corridor.  On his heels is DR. LONNIE WALSH, 33. Lonn is also conspicuously handsome, but he'll always be secon David.  In everything. The look on Blake's face stops David in his tracks.
There's been a train crash near Santa Barbara. They're flying an aortal trauma here now.  How can I ask you this, David...
David rubs his eyes.  Thinks about it.
I can do it, Blake.
His bravery isn't lost on the two nurses, although Chloe exchanges a quick, covert glance with Lonnie.
Is he crazy, Jasmine?   He's been on his feet for fourteen hours.
Chloe, it's been this way since Leslie died.  Losing himself in his work, poor thing...
... I'll give you something to lose yourself in...
(O.S.) Excuse me, miss?

head_text.subj: BEHIND THE COUNTER OF A SMALL-TOWN DINER.

text: Quaint, Midwestern eatery.  Knick-knacks and photos aboun The booths and counter are packed with LOCALS.  A family dining section off in one corner. TWO GUYS sitting at the counter in team jackets.  The old of the two holds up his empty coffee cup.  But his WAITRE standing a couple seats down from him, doesn't move. She' completely absorbed in watching the soap opera that plays two battered, fuzzy TV sets. BETTY SIZEMORE, 30, has a wholesome attractiveness that competes with a bit too much makeup and a cheesy white waitress uniform. TWO OTHER WAITRESSES attend to customer behind her. The younger of the two guys is involved in the soap opera But the older one, still wants coffee.  He gestures towar Betty.
Miss?
Betty leans forward, grabs the coffee pot and moves in fr of him.  Without taking her eyes from the TV, she pours t java, which somehow lands in his cup without spilling a d
(cont'd) Very impressive.  That is very... (turning to others) Did anybody see that?
The LOCAL GUYS around him don't even bother to look up. O course, they've seen it before.  Betty smiles.
(cont'd) Thank you.  Could I bother you for a little more...?
Before he can even finish, Betty is topping him off with milk.
Skim, right? (tears open an Equal) And half a pack, if I remember correct...

The older gentleman's mouth works a bit but nothing comes out.  He is flabbergasted by her attention to detail.  Sh looks at the younger man, who is still following the show gobbling down a huge bacon burger. BETTY (cont'd) You know, you're never too young to start on a lean meat substitute... (BEAT) You wanna try some turkey bacon on that?
You want a tip when I'm through?
It's your body...
Betty turns back to change pots.  The older man watches h intently as the younger of the two mumbles to himself.
(to himself) That's right, so why don't you get up off it...
Wesley... (to Betty) I've told him the same thing.  Thanks for the suggestion.
No problem.

Betty flashes the men a winning smile and moves off, one always on the TV as she approaches two local types. SHERIFF ELDEN BALLARD, 32, a short, tightly wound little sitting at his own booth.  Ballard is spit and polish all way:  creases in his shirt, a glossy shine on his shoes. Badge proudly displayed.  He sits with
ROY OSTREY, 31, a gangly, bookish local reporter.  Betty drops five ketchup packets and four mayonnaise packets on table for him.  Another smile.
Hi, Betty.  You're looking good...
Thanks, Roy, you're sweet... a big liar, but sweet.  I liked your editorial this morning...
Oh, appreciate it.  I was trying to, ahh, give a sense of history to...
(interrupting) Yeah, it was great.  Really put the whole idea of "church bake sales" in perspective...
You know, Elden, some people actually read more than just the Classifieds...
Why don't you go back to doing something you're good at... like that Lonelyhearts column? (chuckles to himself) I'll take a refill there, Betty...
His cup is full before he can even finish the sentence.
Hey, Sheriff.  How's everything?
Oh, you know, the usual... keeping the world safe.
... I meant your food.
Oh, right... 's fine.  Thanks.
I thought you said the eggs weren't...
It's fine.  Mind your own meal...
You should get the order you want.
And you should keep your nose out of another man's omelette... (to Betty) It's no big deal, Betty.
There's yolks in there, huh?  It's no prob'... gotta keep you on track.
Betty grabs Ballard's plate without another word, gives h reassuring rub on the shoulders and moves off.  He smiles appreciatively after her, then turns on Roy.
Why you always gotta embarrass me?  I been eating lunch with you since grade school and you always gotta embarrass me!
They're just eggs, Elden, how embarrassing can eggs be?
... plenty
Who eats eggs for lunch, anyhow?
Mind your own business.  You just said that shit so you could look at her a little longer, anyway...
Still carrying Ballard's plate, she returns to the counte
Come on, guys, I told you it's egg whites only for the Sheriff... (quietly) ... I put him in that 'zone' thing.
Well, it better be a pretty good size zone if he's in it...
Betty and the cooks share a quick laugh.  They move to ch his order while Betty glances up at the TV.
Lonnie catches up to Blake in the corridor.
Blake, I can handle that transplant!
We need someone with the right kind of experience, Lonnie.
Even if he's falling asleep on his feet?
Lonnie, it's a complex procedure.  Why don't you observe?
I'm not some snot-nosed resident fresh out of medical school, Blake.
No, you're not.  You're a good doctor, Lonnie, but you're not David Ravell. I've made my decision.  Now, if you'll excuse me ...
Blake exits.  The camera moves in to hold on a CLOSEUP of Lonnie's face as he simmers in anger.  Music soars.
Plates of food are piling up on the shelf in front of the COOKS.  One of them turns the TV off by remote.
Hey!  We were watching that!
The other girls've got orders up... we're not one 'a them goddamn Nelson families, y'know.
Betty snatches up several plates to help out.  Ballard's appears with A CLATTER of porcelain.
It's "Nielson"...
Yeah, well, we ain't one 'a them, neither.
(BEAT) Go on now...
When you gonna get those things fixed, anyhow?
When you all quit watching 'em for a living...

Frustrated, Betty delivers several plates and drops them tables where the people know her by name.  She moves off toward FOUR LOCAL GUYS in a booth jangling their empty cu Betty weaves her way over to them and pours refills.  Whe hand strays around to touch her ass, she pushes it away w her foot and keeps right on pouring. Absently, Betty take look around the restaurant.  The other waitresses are gon and no one is behind the grill.  Alarmed, she pushes thro the double doors into the kitchen.
THREE WAITRESSES, along with the DISHWASHER and TWO COOKS standing in a row waiting for her.
... alright, I get it, no more TV. Sorry.

No one moves, then DARLENE leads them in a huge SURPRISE! They produce a life-size cardboard cut-out of Dr. David Ravell, who looks dashing in his green hospital scrubs. Betty backs up in disbelief. BETTY (cont'd) Oh my gosh, this is so embarrassing! Where did you ever find this?
On the goddamn internet, where else?
You're joking...
... nope, got him at "T.V. Hunks with Sweet Little Asses.Com."
Seventy-five dollars...
... Seventy-eight fifty. (everyone looks at him)
Well, I paid for the damn thing, I oughta know.
C'mon, Betty!  Pose with him!
Betty laughs and puts her arm around the cardboard man. flash photo is taken.  A cupcake with a single candle is placed in her hands.
One candle... uh-oh, you're getting up there!  Doesn't David like 'em young?
I'm over the hill, what can I say?
Darlene gives Betty an envelope with cash showing.
A little something for those nursing classes you've been wanting to take...
... but keep putting off thanks to a certain husband we won't mention...
Oh, guys, you didn't have to do that!
So how you gonna celebrate?  Del takin' you into Wichita for a big fancy dinner?
The others laugh; they know better.  So does Betty.
Yeah, Dairy Queen, maybe...  Oh, I should probably call him.  Thanks, you guys...
Alright, alright, come on... I'm not running no bed & breakfast, we got customers.  Let's go...
Smiling, Betty grabs a wall phone as the others mingle ab

The trailer/office of a small-time car dealership. As the PHONE RINGS, the CAMERA PANS across pictures of DEL SIZEM 35, dressed as Napoleon, Caesar and Abe Lincoln, arms rai in a high-energy sales pitch.
The PHONE RINGS again.  We see a framed certificate of achievement from General Motors, dated 1986. After the THIRD RING an ANSWERING MACHINE clicks on. It's loud.

(Del's voice) Hello there!  You've reached Sizemore Motors, home of the best selection of used General Motors cars in the Big Springs - Fair Oaks area.  We can't come to the phone right now 'cause we're out making a sale, so leave us a message; better yet, come on down and steal one 'a these beauties right out from under us! Coffee's always on!
Hi Del, it's me.  I guess you're busy.
Del's very busy.  He's on the rented sofa in the trailer' lounge, screwing his secretary, JOYCE.  But as he rocks t couch, he's listening to Betty's message.
I know you want the Oldsmobile back tonight, so... I was wondering if I could take one of the new Buicks.

Del pulls out and lurches across the room.  He reaches fo the desk phone but misses, spilling down onto the carpet. gathers himself and his pants up in disgust, pawing aroun the desktop until he finds the phone.
So, call me when you--
Whoa, whoa, whoa!  Hang on a second there, baby.  Why do you need one of the new Buicks?
Oh, you're there.  You sound out of breath.
I ran back in to get the phone.

The answering machine is on, so their VOICES are BOOMING. phone cord is stretched across the trailer as he tries to back to Joyce.  He motions for her to join him but she remains where she is, fuming.
I don't need one, but it's kind of a special night, and--
What's so special about it?
LONG PAUSE. Joyce looks at Del, incredulous. Then pissed He signals to hold on.
Sue Ann's taking me out and I thought it might be fun to go in a nice car...

Joyce wriggles to a sitting position and begins to pull u her panties.  Del shoots her a look that says 'I'm not finished yet!'  They pantomime frantically back and forth until Joyce throws him the finger and SLAMS out the door.
What was that?
Nothing... it's, ahh, busy here.  Look, you don't need a LeSabre to go out with Sue Ann.  Take the blue Corsica.  I'll see you when I get home.
He throws the phone onto the cradle, then bangs on a wind to get Joyce's attention as she fires up a smoke.
(through the pane) Shit!  Joyce, open the damn gate, will you?!

As Del zips up his pants Joyce trudges across the lot to bring in the "Closed For Lunch" sign and open the gate. silently studies the much nicer car lot next door for a moment.  He takes in the banners, the signs, etc. DEL (cont'd) ... that's what we need, some goddamn flags.
Betty enters the office.  Joyce is on the phone.  She loo up, irritated, and says something under her breath to the caller.
Uhh, no, we haven't picked a date yet... well, once he dumps her we will. (to Betty) He's out pricing banners... I don't expect him back.
"Banners?"
You know, flags and shit... he said "for a livelier look" or something.
Betty nods and swaps her car keys for a set Joyce gives h JOYCE (cont'd) 'S too bad about the LeSabres... they're a really sweet ride.

As Joyce prattles on, Betty notices the Buick LeSabre key a rack behind her.  She sidles around Joyce, deftly remov set from the hook and drops them in her purse.  She smile and starts to wave goodbye as Joyce puts her call on hold JOYCE (cont'd) Need something else?
No, I was just... How you doing?
Great.  Good.  Content...
Oh.  How come?
I dunno.  Job satisfaction, I guess... (BEAT) How's things at the Tip Top?
They're fine... you miss it?
You must be joking.
Hmm. (BEAT) So, Del get that car he sold you up and running yet?
Oh, yeah, he's got things up and running, alright...
'Kay, good.  Bye, then...
Uh-huh. (back to phone) Anyway, I'm thinking Easter, 'cause I just fucking love pastels.
She whispers, then laughs loudly as Betty leaves.

The cardboard doctor is standing next to Betty's Olds.  S thinks about leaving him, but picks him up and tosses him into a blue Corsica.  He lands with his face against the passenger window. She stands for a moment by the Corsica, dangling the LeSa keys before her eyes.  Suddenly, she jumps inside the Chevrolet and slams the door.

The blue Corsica leaves the parking lot and pulls onto th street.  The car makes an abrupt turn into a trailer park directly behind the car lot and glides to a halt behind a of battered airstreams. Betty gets outs of the Chevy and looks back:  the handsom face of Doctor David Ravell is staring at her from the ca
Oh, Christ, what am I gonna do with you?
She goes back to pick him up, then starts off.
A row of cheap trailers on both sides of a crumbling driveway.  Betty appears with her cardboard man tucked un one arm and then disappears behind a pickup truck.

She tosses the cardboard "David" over a concrete slab wal climbs over herself and walks straight to the LeSabres. key opens the last one - maroon. She puts the doctor on t passenger seat, gets in the car and inhales the new car smell. Joyce can be seen inside the trailer, still talking on th phone.  She misses the whole scene as she works on her na
We deserve this.

Betty has the car at 75 m.p.h., on the rural Kansas roads wheat fields for miles on both sides of her.  The RADIO i blasting Bonnie Raitt and she's singing along. She sees her speed and punches the accelerator ... 80 m.p ... 85 ... 90 m.p.h.  She turns the radio up louder. When she approaches a sign saying "You are leaving Kansas Betty suddenly becomes self-conscious.  She eases up on t gas ... slows down ... does a U-turn and heads back towar Fair Oaks.  She glances wistfully in her rear view mirror the billboard that quickly fades into the distance.

Betty enters a modest residential neighborhood and pulls a driveway.  She parks in a detached garage and looks ove the cardboard David.  There's no way he's going in the ho She puts him in the trunk and closes the garage door.

She walks several houses down.  On her way to the door we hear a DOG BARKING, CHILDREN and GENERAL COMMOTION from inside.  SUE ANN ROGERS answers Betty's knock.  Her hair matted with sweat as she struggles with CHILDREN, ages 4, and 6 months.  Suddenly, Sue Ann is hit by an errant rubb ball.
Hey, darling... oww!  Sorry, got my own little Gulf War going on here.
Betty takes the baby as Sue Ann pulls a videotape from a shelf.  It's all one move; they do this every day.
Did you watch it yet?
Sure did. I'll tell you, if that man was any better looking it'd be a crime 'a some sort...
Yep.  Hey, I got a surprise for tonight. We're going to the Starlite in style!
Oh, Betty--
I'll give you a hint.  If you scrunch up your eyes a bit it looks just like a Jaguar...
Honey, I'm really sorry, I was gonna call you about tonight. Larry's got a lodge meeting. There's no way I can get a sitter this fast.
(disappointed) No... what about your sister?
I can't ask her again-- Nathan, stop it! Jesse, don't take that, hit back!-- I feel terrible, hon.
After a beat ...
It's all right.
You sure?  Maybe next week we could...
Uh-huh.  No, we'll do it later.  'S only a birthday, right?  I'll have another one next year...
Betty forces a smile, kisses the baby and hands it back t Sue Ann, who hands her the videotape.
Aahhh... (BEAT) So what color is it?
What?
The LeSabre!
Maroon. (BEAT) I stole it.
What?
He wasn't going to let us use it, so I just took it.
Oh, I wish we could just get in it and drive, and drive, and drive!
Yeah, me too.
Sorry, hon.  Happy Birthday...
I gotta go make dinner.
Betty throws her a look as Sue Ann closes the door.  Bett turns around, frustrated.  She starts yanking her apron o as she crosses the street.

A low-end ranch.  A worn-out sofa and loveseat form an 'L that dominates the living room.  Romance novels line a sm bookcase.  SIX CANARIES in cages chatter away in the kitc Del sits at the dining room table, agitated.  He is prese attacking a pork chop, baked beans and a loaf of Wonderbr All we hear is A FORK CLICKING and BIRDS CHIRPING.  Betty stands at the breakfast counter, barefoot, still in her uniform and quietly eating a salad.
Sure you don't want any salad?
No, I do not want any goddamn... what was all that shit on the phone about the new Buicks?
I told you.  Sue Ann was gonna take me out tonight, but...
She's not comfortable in a Corsica?  'S got air and leather...
I took the blue Corsica, Del.  Relax.
All right, then.  Actually, I'm glad you're going out.  I got something going on tonight.  Some serious clients, with real potential.
Del BELCHES, smiles, then CLUCKS at the birds nearby.
... like the water purifiers?
What?
Or the vitamins?  Or the...?
Del almost comes out of his chair, pointing his finger at her.
Hey, the FDA screwed me on that when they changed the law, and you know it! (BEAT) Anyway, 'least I try shit, still got some dreams left... you're a goddamn waitress, what do you got?
I got you, Del...
... well, then you ain't got much.
Oh, I know. (BEAT) So, who're these clients?
Couple 'a guys in from outta town.  They want to see the new LeSabres.
Betty hides her reaction.
DEL (cont'd) And I don't need Sue Ann's fat ass around to fuck it up...
Just knock it off, 'kay?  Anyhow, they're 97's, they're not even new.
They're new to us...

Truce for a moment.  Del plucks a copy of Soap Opera Guid from Betty's purse while absently taking a bite from Bett cupcake.  He narrowly misses the candle. DEL (cont'd) Jesus... you know these actors are mainly models, which are mainly fags.  They've done studies.  The rest're assholes.  But you know what bugs me most about these soaps?
She silently mimics him as he says... DEL (cont'd) It's people with no lives watching other people's fake lives.
Yeah, I guess there's nothing like watching those tenpins fall, huh, Del?
That is a skill!
Del lurches to his feet and crosses to the bird cages as canaries CHIRP and SING EXCITEDLY at his approach. DEL (cont'd) Daddy's here, babies... daddy's here. (to Betty) Be back later... clean up.
He exits.  She collects his dirty dishes, puts them in th sink and starts to wash them.  Then she stops.
What the hell am I doing?
She drops the dishes with a clatter, pours herself a glas wine, lights the candle on her deflowered cupcake and ope the one card on the table.
a traditional greeting from her grandparents.  Red hearts lace.  A color photo of them enclosed. Betty smiles at this.  After moment, she quietly sings a quick refrain of "Happy Birthday" to herself.
Standing wrapped only in a towel, Lonnie speaks into the phone.
Tell me something good, Sugar.
The beautiful nurse Chloe is curled up seductively on her sofa with her phone in one hand and a cigarette in the ot
We're all set.  I told him my car's in the shop.  He said he'd be happy to give me a ride home.
(V.O.) You're beautiful.
Tell me something I don't know...
Betty hits FAST FORWARD.  Characters flit on and off the screen at top speed until David Ravell appears.
Chloe's magnificent legs are folded into the seat of Davi 560 SL.  She struggles with her seatbelt, so he helps her She makes sure their hands touch.
Thanks for pulling over, David... I can't go that fast without taking a breather.
Sorry... it's nice to see what this little beauty can do, though.  I guess, somehow, all that speed helps me forget the past...
I'm sure it does... (touching the seats) Mmm, leather.  How far do they recline?

David smiles, a little uncomfortable. CHLOE (cont'd) Listen, David, I know I've said it before, but I want to tell you again how sorry I am about your wife. (BEAT) It must make you scared to get close to someone again.
She puts her hand over his on the gear shift.  A moment. Finally, he has to move her fingers to start the car. CHLOE (cont'd) Let's not go... not yet.
BETTY sits on an old couch in the den and watches, eyes g to the screen.  Suddenly, she hears the sound of TIRES ON GRAVEL.  HEADLIGHTS sweep across the window.
Damn!
She hits PAUSE and crosses to look out.

Del gets out of a black Lincoln Town Car, followed by CHA and WESLEY - the guys in the team jackets from the diner. Charlie is 63 years old.  He wears a dress shirt, slacks docksiders.  The suburban father look. Wesley is 28. He's in jeans, T-shirt and white Reeboks. C cut; the kid who used to mow your parents' lawn. Betty quickly snaps out the light and closes the door unt it is open only a crack.
Del swaggers into the house.  The two men follow politely
... you can have the best damn running backs in the world, somebody's still gotta block for 'em.
You're a hundred percent right.  They rely on what's-his-name's arm too much...
Del stops and looks around, deflated by the mess. The den is only a short flight of steps from the living r and the kitchen.  Betty has a clean view of both from whe she sits on the couch.
She hears Del come in, but doesn't take her eyes off the screen.
My apologies, gentlemen.  I asked my wife to straighten this shit up before she went out.
Del crosses to an old stereo and puts on an LP.  He smile the music overtakes the room.  Charlie and Wesley stand nearby, appreciating the quaintness of the surroundings.
Now, what can I get you gentlemen to drink?
Del crosses to the cupboard.  Charlie and Wesley stand leisurely in the living room.
Bourbon, little water, thank you.
Beer, please.
You got it.
Wesley looks at a wedding portrait of Del and Betty.
Hey... you got a fine one right here!
Wesley... (to Del) Your wife's a very lovely woman.  Have I seen her before?
If you ate at the Tip Top you did.
Oh, yes, with the coffee...
Yep, Betty pours a pretty mean cup.
Del reaches into the fridge and produces a Miller for Wes then mixes two drinks and walks into the dining room and Charlie and Wesley follow to the table and sit down.
I like this.  I like doing business in the home. It's cozy... (noticing the card and cupcake) Who's birthday?
Ahh... my wife's.
What'd you get her?
Huh?  Oh, umm, a car. (BEAT) So, to a successful transaction...
They raise their glasses and drink.  Del tosses back his drink in one gulp.
Chloe is on top of David, kissing him on the mouth as he resists.  He finally has to push her away forcibly, and w hear a TEARING SOUND.  Chloe's blouse has been ripped.
I'm sorry, Chloe.
She starts to cry.  David reaches out to comfort her. DAVID (cont'd) It's not that I don't find you attractive.  I'm just not ready...
David looks up to find her lips on his.  In spite of hims he gives in to the warmth of her kiss and responds hungri Betty is mesmerized.
The men have retired into the dining room, sitting or standing around a worn wooded table.  Charlie and Wesley just finishing their drinks.
All right gentlemen, let's get down to it.  I need to know if you're for real.
If we're for real?
You don't exactly look like drug dealers.
Isn't that the point?
Yeah, well,  I don't have time to screw around.  I got buyers in Dallas, Houston and Vegas who are ready to snap this stuff up.
We appreciate that.  But you just poured me a drink, I'd like to enjoy your hospitality for a few minutes.
Fine.  You got five...
It's a nice place you got here.  Real comfortable.  Sweet little town, Fair Oaks.  You like it here?
(laughs) Are you kidding me?  What's to like?
Seems like a nice place.
It is, if you like idiots...
What do you mean?
It's a small town, man.  I never should have left Omaha.  People here think
small.  They act small.  They're a bunch of dumb fucks.
Really?
You better believe it.
Could you give us an example?
Of what?
I'm asking you for an example of one of these dumb fucks being a dumb fuck.
I don't follow...
You're not a dumb fuck, are you, Del?
(warily) No...
I didn't think so.  So, give me an example of a stupid person doing a stupid thing.  Not being stupid, you're equipped to recognize it.
Are we gonna do business here, or not?
Relax, we brought the cash.
I'm just curious.  Can't you give me an example?
(annoyed) All right ... lemme see ... okay, new Burger King opens up.  These assholes get excited and start lining up.  Like it's some five star restaurant.  The place is mobbed.  Right?
Hmmmm.  "Five Stars," huh? (BEAT) Is that stupid, Wesley?
No, that's ignorant.  They just don't know any better.
That's what I thought. (to Del) You better give me another example.
This is bullshit, can we get down to business here, please?
Off a look from Charlie, Wesley produces a pistol and gen nudges the barrel into Del's ear.
Jesus Christ!
He's waiting...
Okay, uh... the, umm, Injuns're stupid.
"Injuns?"
You did not just say "Injuns," Del.
The Indians, Injuns, whatever.  They're always drunk and doing stupid things.
Like what?
Driving their cars into trees... puking on the sidewalk... stupid shit!
Let's see... around here that would be Kiowa, Kickapoo or Osage, if I'm not mistaken.
I... I don't know...
Well, my idea of stupid is very different from yours. (BEAT) So here's how this is gonna work.  Would you take your socks off, please?
My socks?
You heard the man.
Del slowly takes his shoes and socks off.  He's sweating, trembling.
I'm gonna talk to you and when I'm finished, you can answer.  But I don't like being interrupted.  Now roll them into a ball...
Del does it.
Oh, Jesus, please...  Please, God.
... and put them in your mouth.
At a sharp look from Charlie, Del obediently stuffs the s into his mouth and starts to cry.  Wesley produces a roll duct tape and fastens Del's hands to the back of his chai
Betty is glued to the TV, oblivious to the men.  Chloe an David are still talking in his car.  She continues to cry
(V.O.) You're wonderful, Chloe, you are... But I just know there's something special out there for me.
Now I'm gonna tell you what stupid is. Stupid is taking something that doesn't belong to you.  Right Wesley?
That's right.
Stupid is trying to sell it to other people who are, by their very nature, untrustworthy.
That is so right.
Stupid is calling people in Kansas City who are affiliated with the rightful owners of the thing you stole, and trying to sell it to them.  Right Wesley?
Now, that's really stupid.
So you see, we have totally different ideas of what's stupid and what's not. Don't we?
Del nods; crying, sweating. CHARLIE (cont'd) Good.  Now we're getting somewhere.  You agree that you were stupid?

Del nods again.  Wesley collects Charlie's glass and mixe him another drink.  He gets a beer for himself and stands behind Del.  Charlie sips his drink slowly, savoring it. CHARLIE (cont'd) You know, a hundred and fifty years ago you'd have been scalped for that remark about Native Americans.  Right here where your house is - you'd have been scalped.
Hell of a way to die.
It wasn't always fatal, Wesley.  We could scalp Del right now, and he'd be plenty alive to tell us how it feels.
Del's eyes get huge.
It's pretty simple, too. (BEAT)
First you take a knife and just draw a mark right across the hairline.

Wesley produces a long knife and traces a line across the very top of Del's forehead.  Trickles of blood wind their down his brow.  Del is MOANING and PANTING through his so CHARLIE (cont'd) Hold still, Del, we're just talking here... (pointing to a spot) Then you grab a big handful of hair and pull as you cut.  It's amazing how easily the scalp comes off.
A mark, huh?

Wesley takes a jab at Del's forehead with his knife, leav a small cut. Del starts twitching, rocking back and forth as Wesley gr a fistful of his hair. WESLEY (cont'd) Shut the fuck up!  I bleed more than that when I shave...
Del stops moving. He breathes furiously through his nostr
Now.  I want to know the particulars of your stupid act:  how you got what doesn't belong to you, who helped you get it, and of course, where it is now.
Charlie pulls the socks out of Del's mouth.  Del splutter gasping for air.
