Williams, Arizona.  About halfway there, I guess.
Sue Ann is in her kitchen, ignoring the pleas of all thre children.
Halfway where? You've gotta come home. We've been worried sick about you.  Are you alright?
Sue Ann, I thought you of all people would back me up on this, you know what Del's like.  How did he take my note?
Betty, honey, listen to me.  A man came by from Mutual Life Insurance.  He says you've got money comin' to you from Del's policy. (BEAT) Del's life insurance policy-- Are you with me?
What are you talking about?
"A REASON TO LOVE" comes back on the TV.
Tell Del I'm sorry.  I left so quick, but I need to do this.
Do what?
I gotta go.
Betty!  Listen to me!  Del is ...
Betty hangs up.
David is at a bar staring into his drink. Lonnie is with
How you holding up, amigo?
I just wish I knew why she's doing it.
Yeah. Women are an unsolved mystery.
If that little weasel ever walked in here I wouldn't serve him.
I'd slap his face.
I'd kick him in the nuts, if I thought he had any.
There are two empty beer bottles in front of Betty. The T MUSIC and CLOSING CREDITS of "A Reason to Love" are playi Betty pushes the phone back across the bar.
Where you headed, Betty?
Los Angeles, California.
And you called your friend, and she's telling you not to go? (Betty nods) When I went to Europe my friends told me I was crazy.
Europe?  The Europe? (laughs) This is my first time out of Kansas.

I should call you Dorothy. (BEAT) When I left here I went straight to Italy.  Everybody told me not to go.  But I wanted to go to Rome ever since I saw Audrey Hepburn in "Roman Holiday," and goddamnit, I went.
Did you love it?
Sure I loved it!  It was great.
Ellen rinses a few glasses as she talks to Betty.

Let me tell you something.  I got groped by these Tunisian guys who thought I was a slut for wearing shorts, it was hotter than stink the whole time, and I got some kind of weird gum disease from the water. Plus, it ended my marriage--
That's horrible!

No, he was a toad. Even more of a toad than Merle... I just wear the ring to keep the flies away.  Rome was the best thing I ever did, because I DID IT!  And I swear to you, it changed me.  I've been to Rome, Italy!  I sat every morning at the Cafe Sistina and had my cappuccino, and watched the pilgrims walk to mass, and no one can ever take that away from me.
Betty leans across the bar conspiratorially.  She looks a Merle to make sure he won't hear her.
I left my husband two days ago.
Really?
I'm getting back with my ex-fianc.  He proposed to me right around here, so I guess this is just sort of a sentimental stop...
Wait, I thought you said you'd never been outta Kansas...
Oh.  I mean, except for that. (BEAT) Yep.  I'm trading in a car dealer for a heart specialist, so that's pretty good...
Nice move.  Cedars Sinai?
No.  Loma Vista.
(laughs) I s'pose his name's David Ravell.
(truly shocked) How did you know?
What's his real name?
Dr. David Ravell.
You mean... George McCord, the actor?
No, I mean David Ravell. He's a surgeon.
Ellen looks at Betty.
Yeah, I know, we just watched him together, remember?  Up there on the TV. (off Betty's earnest look) Good God Almighty ... You're serious. I've heard about people like you.
Ellen whistles, wipes the bar down to buy a few seconds. Merle looks over at Betty, then catches Ellen's eye.
Piss off, Merle. (to Betty) So how you gonna find him, Betty?
I'll go to the Hospital.
What if you can't find him?  What if you get out there, and nothing's the way you thought it was gonna be?
Like Rome?
Worse.
You made out alright.
Yeah, but at least I knew Rome was gonna be there when I arrived...
Ellen walks to the end of the bar and starts rinsing glas After a beat, Betty gets up and moves down close to her.
Ellen, this is the biggest thing I've ever done, but I've gotta do it.
You take care of yourself then, Betty, and don't let anybody stop you...
To tell you the truth, I can't believe I've made it this far.  It may not be Europe, but I just know there's something special out there for me...

Ellen looks into Betty's eyes - sees the innocence, the h and enthusiasm - and has to look away. Betty takes it as cue to leave. She smiles, puts two dollars on the bar nea the phone and leaves.  Ellen stands perfectly still, watc the door.
What planet is she from?
Betty approaches the GRAND CANYON, driving slowly along t South Rim, searching for a specific spot.  Finally, she p over abruptly. This is it. We can tell by the joy in her expression.

Betty walks to the rail and gazes out at the canyon. Turn her head slowly, as if expecting it, she sees DAVID RAVEL leaning on the rail about twenty feet away, clutching a bouquet of roses. Betty starts toward him... he starts toward her... A magi moment... Shattered when a black sedan appears, inching i way along. She freezes. David vanishes, and ... An ELDERLY MAN helps his wife out of the car and snaps he picture in front of the canyon.  Betty moves away.
Charlie and Wesley drive across Kansas farm country.
So she gets rid of the asshole and is set for life in the same day.
You think so?  Joyce says she's timid.
Joyce was screwing Del.
... among others.
I'd say that about torches her credibility, wouldn't you?
Yeah, well, if the wife's trying to sell it she'll fuck up.  She's an amateur, just like Del was.
The CAR PHONE RINGS.  Charlie answers.
Maybe... (into phone) Yes?
Is this Neighborly Life Insurance?
Sorry, you've got the wrong number.
He hangs up.
No, I see Betty as a Midwestern Stoic type.  Ice water in her veins.  A clear thinker.  Probably a Swede or a Finn.
A 'Finn?'  What is a Finn?

You should read more.  Listen to me.  I think this woman was waiting for a chance to do this, and we gave it to her.  She kept to herself for years, living with a pompous asshole.  Then she sees her opportunity, and BOOM! - she leaves that little mudpatch in the dust.  These heartlanders can't figure it out, 'cause that's not their sweet little Betty. Hah!  We've been tracking her for, what, three days and I already understand her better'n most the people in that shitty little burg.
Charlie pulls out the close-up photo and studies it. CHARLIE (cont'd) Betty, Betty, Betty...
So what the fuck's a Finn?
Oh, for Chrissakes.  It just means the kind of person who can eat shit for a long time without complaining, then cut their momma's throat and go dancing the same night.
Like... us?
No,... like a worthy adversary, Wesley. Like a very worthy adversary.

Roy approaches his fish tank cautiously.  He leans down a looks at the piranha as a TV commercial ends and "A Reaso Love" comes on. He then returns to his computer, struggling to find the r words and to type them with only one hand.  He types a little, stares at the screen, then deletes an entire sent one character at a time, hammering on the 'Delete' key. glances up at the television as the words 'Chloe' and 'Lonnie' are repeated.
Roy and Sue Ann go straight to Ballard's office, where th find him at his desk eating lunch out of tupperware containers.  He wears a napkin tucked into his shirt-top.
What the hell do you want?...  Hey, Sue Ann, what's up?
We think we know where Betty is.
Ah, shit... Do I have to hear this now?
What's with the tupperware, Elden, did Meredith run outta baggies?
No reason to get a plate dirty.
I see you're sticking to the diet Betty put you on...
Worry about your own goddamn lunch!
(excited; to Sue Ann) Tell him what you told me.
Betty is a big, big fan of the soap opera, "A Reason to Love." Look...
She tosses a copy of "Soap Opera Digest" on the desk. Bal ignores it and keeps eating.
Why do I need to see this?  Did he ask you to...?
Listen!  I saw 'Chloe' and 'Lonnie' on T.V.  They're television characters.
Betty's in love with Dr. David Ravell, from the show.  What if she's out in Los Angeles looking for him?  The actor, I mean...
That's the dumbest thing I've ever heard.
Yeah?  Well, she called Sue Ann yesterday from Arizona.
She said she was in Arizona, did she?
Yes!!
You people are even more stupid than I thought.  The woman's on the run and she's gonna just phone in her location?
Come on, Elden, she's not on the run. Couldn't you at least call the Los Angeles Police Department?
You gotta do that much.
Hey, I'm the law.  I don't gotta do nothing...
The Lincoln pulls into the dusty, overgrown driveway and front yard of a derelict farm.

The remains of pie and coffee on the table, Charlie and Wesley kick back with JERROLD BLAINE and his wife ELIZABE both in their 80's.  Photos of Betty at various ages lie scattered in front of them. Charlie holds up a picture of a young Betty in ballerina costume posing at the barre.  He studies it intently.
This is Betty at twelve.
Very graceful.  Perfect form.
Betty was a lovely child.
And she always had such spirit!  But, after her mother died...
Would you say she was ambitious?
Oh, there's no tellin' what that girl could've accomplished, and she never had it easy.  Never really had a childhood... caring for her father, going to school.
Charlie admires a photo of Betty, around 18 years old.  H continues to rummage through a box of collectibles, pocke a small child's diary when it is convenient.
Wise beyond her years, I'm sure, and such poise, too. (quietly) Very, very impressive...
Well, then, did you ever get any indication that she wanted to leave her husband?

I don't like talking bad about the dead, but now that he's gone I can tell you she put up with things in that marriage I wouldn't have.  And yes, she, of all people, was the one who defended him. And that's why what that sheriff said makes me so angry.
What do you mean?
If anyone had paid to have that husband of hers killed, it would have been me.
(taking her hand) Mrs. Blaine?  I can tell you right now, without a doubt, that your granddaughter is alive, and did not kill Del Sizemore.
You've got to be missing a piece of your soul to kill someone. That's not our Betty...
(defensive) ... why do you think you have to be missing a piece of your soul to kill somebody?
Because it ain't natural, young man.
What are you talking about?  Killing's totally natural.  It's dying that isn't natural...

(covering) My partner's still young, Mr. Blaine, and he loves his job. (laughs) He'd like to kill all the criminals himself! (BEAT) Now, if Betty was running from someone, where do you think she'd go?

location: BETTY'S LESABRE/ EXT. COUNTY USC HOSPITAL

text: Betty drives through Boyle Heights - East L.A., holding a and checking street signs.  She is wearing a brand new Nurse's uniform.  Up ahead, she sees the hillside complex L.A. County/USC Hospital.  Hurriedly, she pulls over and checks herself in the visor mirror.  She is underwhelmed.
God... I still look like a waitress.
The CHIEF NURSE, a large, dynamic woman in her 50's, face Betty across her desk.
Of course, I don't know every doctor who works here...

Dr. Ravell's the finest surgeon on the staff.  You must know him.  He's incredibly handsome, gentle, considerate. He's being sued for sexual assault right now, but-- (Off Chief Nurse's look) It's not true.  He was set up.
Well, I certainly would have heard about that.
Of course, he's only here two days a week.  He's also on staff over at Loma Vista.
... I don't think I know that hospital.
It's in a very pretty area that gets a lot of sun, has palm trees out front, mountains in the background...
Really?  You've just described all of Southern California.
The Chief Nurse looks at Betty for a moment, then stands abruptly, signaling the end of the interview.
(cont'd) Well, I'm sorry, but I can't even consider you without references or a resume.  And frankly, I don't know how you could have forgotten them.

On her way down the hall Betty passes a patient's room wh the sound of A PERSON MOANING stops her.  She can't help go inside.  A TV plays commercials. AN OLDER WOMAN lies in bed, alone and staring at the ceil Betty looks around and notices several arrangements of flowers on a deserted nightstand.  She brings them over t the older woman's bedside, positions them, then gently strokes her head.
There... you rest now.
The woman's eyes flutter.  She is disoriented at first, t calms as she adjusts to the comforting sight of Betty.  B takes her hand.
Who... who're you?
I'm... I'm Nurse Betty.

The woman smiles serenely at this and begins to drift off Betty checks her monitors as the opening credits of "A Re to Love" begin to play. She glances up at the doorway at the same moment and sees David Ravell standing at the entrance.  He checks the cha on the door, smiles warmly at Betty and then moves off. flash, Betty is up and after him. The THEME MUSIC is her private soundtrack as she checks o every man in surgical scrubs, looking for David Ravell. Then... She sees him.  In all his glory at the end of a corridor walking away from her.  Betty gives chase.  She gains steadily on him, her heart racing.  As they near Emergency the NOISE LEVEL picks up. He stops at the nurses' station.  Betty closes the gap. starts to run.
DAVID!!!
He turns to face her ... It's not David Ravell. BETTY (cont'd) Sorry, I thought you were someone else. (BEAT) Do you know Dr. David Ravell?
The man shakes his head.  Betty keeps going, looking arou it's incredible - the size, the activity, the intensity.

DOZENS OF PATIENTS lie on gurneys awaiting treatment in a holding area.  It's still more intense at the entrance: VOICES talking back and forth urgently, POLICE OFFICERS, CIVILIANS, DOCTORS AND NURSES converging.

FIVE AMBULANCES unload patients at the same time.  At tha moment a group of TWENTY JAPANESE HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATORS reaches the E.R. portion of their tour. A WHITE MERCEDES tears up the ramp and SCREECHES to a sto A YOUNG MAN in gang colors is pushed out, bleeding heavil A DOCTOR runs at the Mercedes to head it off, yelling indignantly.  The car plows right into him and takes off. Another ambulance crests the ramp, lights flashing.  The Mercedes SLAMS into it head-on.  NURSES AND DOCTORS run i the parking lot. A GANGBANGER gets out of the Mercedes, d and wobbly.  He pulls a pistol.  Everyone dives for cover The Mercedes driver is unconscious. The driver of the sma up ambulance is slumped over the wheel.  The rear doors f open, and a young Hispanic woman, ROSA HERRERA, leaps out
SOMEBODY HELP US!  PLEASE, SOMEBODY!

Doctors and nurses work on patients and try to get to the injured doctor, but the kid with the gun keeps them away. SECURITY GUARDS draw their guns and scream at him to drop ROSA (cont'd) WHY ISN'T ANYBODY HELPING US?!! (to gunman in Spanish) Hey, you little shit!  If I had a gun I'd shoot you right now!
The loading area is jammed with panicked people.  Doctors nurses creep out of the hospital on all fours, trying to
low.  No one is getting to Rosa, whose frantic eyes find Betty.  They look right at each other. ROSA (cont'd) What are you standing there for?!
Betty walks toward her calmly, indifferent to the danger Rosa pulls the gurney out of the ambulance herself.  A PARAMEDIC lies unconscious inside. ROSA (cont'd) You gotta help him, he's hurt bad!!
On the gurney is a YOUNG MAN with a chest wound, nearly d from blood loss.  A DOCTOR appears and quickly examines h while keeping one eye on the gunman.  He looks up at Bett
Forget it!  He doesn't have a chance. Help us over here.
The doctor takes off.  Rosa looks at Betty, crying.
Please!
Betty hesitates, then checks his pulse - he has none.  Sh peels back the bandages over a huge chest wound.
Danny, it's gonna be all right!
Betty looks at Rosa again; looks around for help - there' one.  She plunges her fingers into the wound. ROSA (cont'd) (panic) What are you doing?
He has no heartbeat!
You're hurting him!!
I'm massaging his heart.  I saw it done once.
ARE YOU CRAZY?!!  STOP IT!!!
LISTEN TO ME!  IF I DON'T DO THIS, HE'S DEAD!
She keeps working on him.  We hear a GUNSHOT, and the kid with the pistol falls to the pavement.  The loading area immediately fills with DOCTORS, NURSES and COPS.
All right, we're moving him inside!  Give me a hand!
Rosa is shocked into motion. Together they wheel Danny to the entrance.  A DOCTOR and TWO NURSES come out to take o Betty, her white uniform now covered in blood, steps asid
The DOCTOR tries to calm Rosa and keep her from entering treatment area.
Is he gonna live?
He's got a chance.  Thanks to what that nurse did.
They exit together as AN ADMINISTRATOR and several Japane officials approach.  The Chief Nurse hovers nearby.
(to Chief Nurse) Harriet?  Who is that remarkable nurse?
That's Betty Sagamore.  I hired her today.
SEVERAL LOW LIFES are hanging out in the lobby.  When Bet comes in with a bag of groceries they look up, ready to hassle her as she approaches the DESK CLERK.
May I have my key, please?
She puts the bag on the counter, revealing that the front her white uniform is covered with blood.  She smiles at t low lifes, stopping them in their tracks.
The Town Car's looking a little muddy around the rims. Charlie and Wesley look tired as they wait in a seedy mot
room.  Charlie sits near a window, reading diary entries aloud.  Wesley kicks back on the bed, fast-forwarding thr "Genghis Kunt" and talking back to the screen.
Thas' it, thas' it... conquer that bitch. (BEAT) What time're they coming?
It's not an exact science, Wesley.  He said they'll be here... My Houston contact has always been very reliable.
And then we're gonna do her right here. Right?

You're always so coarse... "Do her right here."  Let's just see what happens, okay? (reading) "I wish that I could find a way; To speak my thoughts on Mother's Day.  There are no words that quite express; My gratitude or happiness.  A pleasant smile perhaps a kiss; I would not fail to give her this. I'd make her glad the whole day through; By sayin' 'Mother', I love you!'  P.S. I wish I could say this to my mother's face, but I can't anymore."

Wesley rolls his eyes and turns up the volume.  Finally a pulls up outside and Charlie snaps the book closed.  He m a quick attempt to arrange himself and motions to Wesley, turns off the tape. A WOMAN with greasy blonde hair and skinny legs shown off a short skirt comes in with another MAN.  Charlie looks h over disgustedly as his face falls. CHARLIE (cont'd) Who are you?! (to the man) What the... Who the hell is this?
Easy, Charlie!  She's exactly who you said you were looking for.
Wait, wait a minute.  We have a major miscommunication here.  This not Betty. This is not even close to Betty...
What the fuck're you talking about?  My name's Betty...
Then I'm sorry... Wrong Betty.
Let's get out of here.  We got another long drive ahead of us. (BEAT) ... the fuck where I do not know, but I know it's gonna be long.
(gathering his things) Betty would never dress like that.  She's not some trailer park slut!
Fuck you!
And she doesn't have a sewer for a mouth...
Okay, thank you, goodbye... Keep in touch...
... She's got class, and poise.  Lots of poise...
The man looks at Charlie, then at Wesley, who shrugs in r as he steers them out the door.
Will you ease off on the 'poise' shit, you're spooking me here...
The Chief Nurse sits behind her desk.  Betty faces her li student in the principal's office, now dressed in her whi waitress uniform.  She hopes no one notices.
What you did yesterday was reckless at best.  You are not an employee of this hospital!  If that boy dies I don't even want to think of the lawsuit that'll follow.  Are we communicating here?
Yes, ma'am.

Good.  I'm prepared to offer you a job. You can help out in the pharmacy until your California certification and references arrive, but you are not to touch anyone.  Is that totally clear? (Betty nods) Fine...
The Chief Nurse gets up, and Betty follows suit.
(cont'd) You can start tomorrow.  And don't say a word about this to anyone. (studying Betty's uniform) Is that issue?
Umm... yes.  Back home.
Alright.  Oh, and one more thing about what you did yesterday... Well done.
Danny Herrera is in bed unconscious.  Rosa and her MOTHER keeping vigil when Betty enters. Rosa jumps to her feet.
Hey, it's Supernurse!  Betty, right?
Rosa hugs her and tells her mother in Spanish who Betty i ROSA (cont'd) My mother doesn't speak English.
Sra. Herrera smiles at Betty and starts to cry.  As she s forward, Rosa stands aside. The short, stocky woman envel Betty in a bearhug.
No podremos olvidar lo que hizo ayer.
(translating) We can't forget what you did yesterday ... How can my family ever repay you?
Tell her I was just--
Yo s que es su empleo, pero...
She doesn't care if it was just your job...  Danny would be dead now but for you.

Sra. Herrera kisses Betty's hands and smiles through her tears.  Then she motions to Rosa to take her place as she goes to Danny's bedside. Betty picks up Danny's chart and reads it. ROSA (cont'd) You don't sound like you're from here.
I'm not.  I just drove in from Kansas.
So why'd you come to L.A.?
I came for love.  My fianc  is here.
Bravo! Mi hija no hace nada para amor...
You're making me look bad... My mother says I wouldn't move across the street for love.
It's something I had to do.  For David.
'David.'  That's your guy.  So, you staying with him?
THE ICU NURSE enters and adjusts the bank of machines feeding, medicating and monitoring Danny. Betty watches w interest.
No... I don't really know where he is yet.  I'm at a hotel around the corner.
Man, that is love.
Ella debe quedar contigo.
What?  Ahh, Mom says you should stay with me... Okay, yeah, why not?
Betty looks at Sra. Herrera curiously.
You can go get your stuff right now. I'll walk you down.
No, that's not, I couldn't...
Listen, when someone does the kind of thing you did, you gotta do something in return.  So, you stay with me until you find your David and live happily ever after.  Okay?
Rosa follows Betty out the door.
Betty and Rosa make their way up the stairs of a Silverla apartment house. At the sound of SCREECHING TIRES they both look down as a black Lincoln Town Car drives by.  Betty shudders.
You okay?  This neighborhood, you get used to it...
She nods. Rosa continues to talk as they climb the many stairs that lead to her door. ROSA (cont'd) I got this apartment with a guy.
The one you were telling me about?

No, this one was worse...I had to have the place sprayed when he left.  Twice... He was two guys before the last one--not counting a little office thing in there, which I'm trusting you with, 'cause if it gets out, I'm on the street...
The place is neat.  As well furnished as a legal assistan salary will allow.  The living room is dominated by a lar glass tank filled with tropical fish.  Betty checks out t space.
It's lovely...I really like your aquarium.
Yeah, well, at least fish don't use your razor or pee on the seat...
Hmmm. Sounds like you've had a pretty tough go of it with men...
Oh, I dunno...but just once I wish I'd run into a guy who noticed the Koi before my tits.
Betty smiles, a little embarrassed. ROSA (cont'd) ...come on, I'll show you your room.
The black Lincoln Town Car is parked on a lonely stretch prairie highway.  Wesley sits in the passenger seat with door open. The RADIO is on. Charlie is on his cell phone nearby.
(into phone) No, we don't know where she is... I understand... No, we'll find her... (BEAT) I understand.
He hangs up and looks out at the horizon, where huge blac storm clouds are gathering.  Then he walks slowly to the of the car, staring at the ground in front of his feet.
What'd they say?  Can we go back to Detroit?
Charlie rests his hands gently on the hood, as if conside buying the car.  Wesley's MUSIC BANGS from the radio.
They said find it.  Find her, find it. Finish the job you were paid to do.
Half.
What?
They paid us half.  They still owe us half...

(disappointed) There it is again.  That lousy attitude that got us here in the first place. That "make a statement," do an end zone dance, shake your ass and sue everybody in sight attitude that's dragging this whole country down the drain. (BEAT) They don't owe us shit, Wesley!  WHEN YOU FINISH THE JOB, YOU GET PAID!!  WE HAVEN'T FINISHED THE GODDAMN JOB!!

Charlie POUNDS on the hood of the car, scaring Wesley. CHARLIE (cont'd) That woman could be in any one of four states.  Four big states where the deer and the antelope play, Wesley!  We're not in Rhode Island!
I know that.
AND TURN THAT FUCKING MUSIC OFF!

Wesley switches it off.  Charlie turns his back to the ca and addresses the angry clouds on the horizon. CHARLIE (cont'd) Do I deserve this?  In the twilight of my career, do I deserve this?  I don't think so!  I've always tried to do what's right.  I never took out anybody who didn't have it coming.  I'm a professional! (BEAT) AND WHERE THE FUCK AM I?  I'M IN PURGATORY!
Worse... you're in Texas.
Well, I should be in FLORIDA now!  If Carl hadn't gone in to get those stones removed, you wouldn't be here and I'd be on my way to the Keys.  On my boat, RELAXING WITH A GLASS OF PORT!!  Re-ti red!

The first raindrops begin to fall. CHARLIE (cont'd) I'm very tired, Wesley!  I've worked hard, and the work should be over, but IT'S NOT!  This job is just beginning. (he turns around) GET IN THE CAR!

Wesley is in the car, but he's too scared to tell Charlie whose eyes are blazing.  Charlie silently walks around to driver's side and gets in.  He and Wesley stare at each o over a photo of Betty, which is between them on the dash. Charlie starts the engine and snatches up the picture. CHARLIE (cont'd) What're you thinking, girl?  What's going on in that pretty little mind of yours? Huh?  You can tell me...
He paws at the picture, imploringly.  He mutters to himse Wesley shakes his head and stares out.
Betty sits in an office along with a CLERK who taps away computer keyboard while she studies a printed list of nam
I can't find Loma Vista Hospital...
I never heard of Loma Vista Hospital.
I don't believe this!  You're the second person here who's told me that.  That's like Ford saying they never heard of GM!
Try another county...
He exits.
Rosa is on the phone at her desk in a law office.
Hey, Rosa...it's Betty. How do you get to this town called 'Tustin?' It's in Orange County...
Tustin?  Take the Hollywood Freeway to the Five...
The Five?
Just look for the really crowded road and follow that.
Okay...oh, umm, would you mind if I borrowed some clothes?
Huh?  Sure, look in my closet, take any dress you want! (BEAT) We're still on for tonight, right?

Betty stands in a sexy pink dress, trying to decide if sh should put on a hospital gown and waits, tensing each tim she hears a voice from the hallway.  Finally, the DOORKNO BEGINS TO TURN. A man's hand and the bottom of a white sleeve appear.  Th door swings open and a silver-haired, bespectacled DOCTOR his mid-60's enters.  The nametag on his white coat reads
Tasteful jazz, plenty of red leather booths.  Betty winds way through a PACKED CROWD, passing out small white cards Rosa spots her and goes over to meet her.
You made it! Hey, that looks great on you.  'S classy... (BEAT) So, how'd it go today? You find him?
Ummm...no, no. Different 'Ravell.'
Rosa starts to lead her to the bar. BETTY (cont'd) You know, the more I think about it, this really isn't David's kind of place.

What are you talking about?  This bar is packed with professional people! (BEAT) Everybody says if you're going to get married, this is the spot to meet someone...  Luckily, I'm currently off men, so I've got the luxury of not giving a shit.
I know what you mean, I recently had some trouble with a man, a different man...and David's still getting over Leslie. (off Rosa's look) His wife.
He has a wife?!
Had. She died in a car accident last year.  She was decapitated.
God, that's awful!
It may not have been an accident.  They never did find her head...
Her 'head'?! You're making this up...
No, no! Well, see, she was having an affair with a Russian diplomat who I believe was mixed up with the Mafia...
Jesus, I thought my love life was crazy...

Rosa and Betty are sitting in a booth, talking over drink The place is a little quieter now. ROSA (cont'd) ... so, we'll hit the library first and fan out from there.  They've got all the L.A. phone books, plus medical directories... (BEAT) We're not gonna let him hide from you any more, okay? I'm making this my personal mission.
David isn't hiding from me, I left him standing at the altar six years ago and now I'm...

Fuck the details, they're always to blame...  Look, too many of these guys duck out on us, especially after they become doctors or lawyers.  I see it at my company all day long!  So I'm just gonna make sure you get your, you know, fairy tale ending or whatever... (BEAT) One of us should.
Rosa, I can't believe you're doing all this for me...thank you.
Rosa glances over to see Betty pass a business card to A WAITER who checks on them.  When he is safely gone, Rosa touches Betty on the sleeve.
Hey, how 'bout a card for me?  What is that? (takes one, reads) "Please call if you have any information on David Ravell."  This is my phone number!  How many of these have you given out?
How many men have I talked to?
Jesus!  They're all gonna be calling me!
You said in L.A., anything goes.
I was talking about what you could wear!

The Town Car's parked on a barren stretch of desert highw white smoke billowing from the hood.  Half a mile ahead Charlie and Wesley are walking in the sweltering heat. They're in their shirtsleeves, drenched in sweat as the s beats down on them.

See, in a LeSabre Betty's probably getting twenty-two, maybe twenty-five miles to the gallon, where we're topping out at fifteen. (BEAT) She's probably all cool and fresh, and comfortable in that nice air-conditioned car right now.

Wesley wipes the sweat from his eyes and trudges on in silence. Charlie takes out a photo of Betty and speaks to CHARLIE (cont'd) You don't look comfortable here.  That's 'cause you don't like being the center of attention, do you?  Nah. You're like me.
What the hell's the matter with you?

Wesley grabs the photo, tears it in half and tosses it. T he starts walking. Charlie is stunned for a moment, but recovers quickly. He finds the pieces and stuffs them in pocket, then catches up to Wesley.
That was a really shitty thing to do.
I'm sick of looking at her mother-fucking face.
A beat... they walk for a moment.
Don't talk like that.  She's my last one, Wesley, my final target. (to photo) Don't you realize your special, that you represent something?
This is too much.  Wesley explodes.
What?  What does she represent?!  What could some cornbread white bitch from Kansas who's dragging our sorry asses up and down the Louisiana Purchase possibly mean to you?!!  I'd just love to know...
I dunno... something. (BEAT) Why is she doing this to me?  Why?...
I don't know, but when we find her she's gonna die for it.
The Lincoln Town Car is raised up high on the hydraulic j Wesley is at a pay phone out front.
Can you describe her to me?... Okay... Yeah, that sounds like her... Thanks.
He hangs up and goes into the garage, where he addresses Town Car above him. WESLEY (cont'd) They found her in Vegas.
No answer. WESLEY (cont'd) Perfect match on the description.
Lying across the front seat taping the reassembled photo Betty to the dash.  Charlie's beginning to come apart.  H hair is uncombed and his clothes are wrinkled.  His eyes a thousand-yard stare.
Sounds like she's with the buyer Del lined up.
Charlie pulls himself up on the door and looks down.
How'd they describe her?
You know, blonde, thin, whatever...
Not so fast!  Slower... 'blonde, thin', yes... Did they say she had style?  A kind of grace or anything?
Wesley rolls his eyes, then goes straight to the levers controlling the hydraulic jack.
(to mechanic) How do I get this fucking thing down?
I wouldn't if I were you.  He got pretty upset when I tried it...
MERCEDES LOPEZ, early 40's, impeccably dressed, enters he office loaded down with a bulging briefcase and a stack o files under her arms. (The entire scene is in Spanish.)
What do you think my father would do if I told him I didn't want to be a lawyer anymore?
Probably the same thing my mom would do if I got engaged... have a heart attack.
So how's it going with your new roomie? What's her name?
Betty.  It's O.K. except I'm worn out. We spent all weekend looking for her
doctor-boy.  How can a big time heart guy leave no trace of himself?
So tell her to settle for the old one in Orange County.
She's gonna have to 'cause I'm out of ideas.
Maybe we're suing him for malpractice. What's his name again?
David Ravell.
God, that sounds so familiar.  Ravell, Ravell... where's he out of?
I'm not sure now.  She said he used to be over at Loma Vista.  I never heard of it.
Loma Vista? (laughs) You mean like the guy on "A Reason to Love?"

Rosa enters, tosses her purse on the table and goes strai to the VCR.  Written in magic marker on a video is "A Rea to Love, Apr. 23."  The tape Sue Ann gave to Betty. She pops it in and turns it on. The OPENING TITLES start The characters appear ... one is an impossibly handsome m over the title "DOCTOR DAVID RAVELL."
Betty working at a desk in the pharmacy.  The same clerk before busies himself at another counter.  Rosa appears a the glass partition and raps urgently on it.
Guess who I saw today.
Who?
Doctor David Ravell.
What?  Where was he?!
ON TELEVISION!! (off Betty's puzzled look) Cut the shit, will you!
A BEAT.  Rosa SLAMS the videotape down on the counter.
Either you're making a fool out of me because you get off on it, or you got serious problems.  Which one is it?!
I have no idea what you're talking about.
I'M TALKING ABOUT DAVID RAVELL!!
Shhh!  I heard you the first time.
(suddenly calm) I spent my weekend looking for someone who does - not - exist.  I should have been here at the hospital with my brother, but I was with you.
If you didn't want to do it, you should have said so!  Is this about gas money?

IT'S NOT ABOUT GAS MONEY!! (BEAT) You have a thing for an actor on a stupid white soap opera, and we searched all over town for his character!  Not the actor - whose name is George, by the way. His character!
Rosa stands over Betty, fuming.
Are you having a nervous breakdown?
Rosa SCREAMS and smacks her hand on the glass as Betty watches.  SEVERAL PEOPLE in a nearby lounge look up.  Ros stares at them until they look away.
BETTY (cont'd) Why'd you help me in the first place?
I helped you because I'm an idiot!  Ask my mother, I love it when people take advantage of me!  I TRUSTED YOU!! I THOUGHT HE WAS REAL!
HE IS REAL!!
Betty tries to return to her work but Rosa confronts her loudly.  The nearby VISITORS and STAFF pretend to be busy
You need help, Betty! Even if this is your idea of a joke, you need SERIOUS HELP!! (walking away - to herself) Necesitas un mdico! Pront simo!

fuming in her humiliation.  After a moment, Rosa reappear the window. ROSA (cont'd) I'm not going back on our arrangement. My word is good, and my family owes you. But I think it's best for both of us if you get your own place as soon as you can.
Fine.

Roy and Joyce approach the door to the trailer/office.  S takes out her key, then stops. It's been padlocked and ba with yellow police tape, as is the whole lot.  Roy pulls on the lock, then starts looking around.
You're wastin' your time, Roy.
Look Joyce, I need your key to the files, not advice, okay?  This is a complex case.
Roy works on opening a side window.
Nothin' complex about it. Del's dead, Betty's gone.  She's probably dead, too.
You'd like that wouldn't you?  You've hated Betty since you were in Pep Squad together...
No... before that.
Ahh, I hate this town!  Places like this just make you small... (BEAT) I should have never come back here after college.
Blah - blah - blah...  Hurry up, will ya, I got a date tonight...
Roy forces the glass open and starts to squirm through th window as Joyce watches. JOYCE (cont'd) I don't know what you think you'll find, anyway.

Names, a phone number, something... (BEAT) Listen, Ballard told me that the guy who brought the missing car down from Detroit was murdered, but do you see him doing anything about it?  If Ballard wasn't such a stubborn ass, I wouldn't have to be breaking in here...
The color drains from Joyce's face.
What did you say?
The driver was killed. I think there's a connection--
(starting to cry) No, about... Are you talking about Duane Cooley?
Yeah.  Why, you know him?
(crying) Know him?  We were gonna get married! He was gonna leave his wife for me! Fuck!!...
Joyce begins to sob at the side of the trailer as Roy shimmies through the window frame. Suddenly, Ballard is there, weapon cocked and placed roug into Roy's privates.  Joyce backs away.
I know you don't use them, but if you wanna keep 'em you'll back out of there slowly...
Roy is in the rear of the car, handcuffed to the screen dividing the front seat from the back. Ballard is driving
Come on, Elden, think about it.  The driver, all them trunks standing open like that... something's going on here!
I know that...
Well, do something, then, damnit!

You watch your mouth when you're in a goddamn county vehicle... You don't think I see what's going on?  Del, now this Cooley fella, both of 'em mixed up with Joyce... 'S not no conspiracy, not some episode off the X-Files... 's just a crime of passion, plain and simple. Betty's on some kind'a pre-minstral rampage, that's what is going on here.
A moment of silence as they drive.
Oww... Did you have to make these things so tight?
No, I didn't have to.
He grins at Roy in the rearview mirror.
Mercedes Lopez arrives at the office and stops at Rosa's desk. (The entire scene is in Spanish)
Hey... Is Betty still trying to find that soap opera guy?
Oh, yeah... Man, I'd love to find that actor just to see the look on her face, watch her bubble burst in mid-air.
Mercedes hands her two tickets to a benefit.
Here's your needle... He's supposed to make an appearance here tonight.
Betty's lying on her bed reading "Modern Nurse".  The L.A Times Classifieds are open on the bed.  Rosa looks in.
Don't worry, I'm looking... just taking a tiny break.
This is crazy.  I come home, you go to your room.  You go in the kitchen, I go to my room.  It's stupid.
Betty nods in agreement. ROSA (cont'd) So what do you say?  Can we be friends?
...okay.
Rosa smiles and starts looking at the tickets in her hand BETTY (cont'd) What are those for?
Oh, it's a charity dinner.  The money goes to a good cause, but I don't have anybody to go with...
Umm...
Rosa exits for a moment, then reappears in the doorway.
...you hungry at all?

The car is covered in dust and mud from the road. It's wo inside: food wrappers, empty bottles, pieces of clothing, filthy windows.  They've been living in it. Wesley's driving now. Charlie's almost unrecognizable: a day beard, uncombed greasy hair, bloodshot eyes, rumpled clothes and an exhausted, faraway look.  The photo of Bet faces him, taped to the glove box.  He is reading from th diary, which he clutches like the Bible. They roar along a desert highway, passing a sign that say "Grand Canyon, This Exit.  74 Miles."  Charlie looks up, marking his place.
We should go.
We don't have time to look at a hole in the ground.  We can make Vegas in four hours.  This one's got to be her.
It's a very moving experience, trust me.
No.
One of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World.
No... be dark before we get there.  You wanna see the Grand Canyon at night?
What difference does it make?  She wasn't in Kansas City, or Houston, or Dallas. We
went to every goddamn place Del mentioned and no Betty.  So what the hell makes you think she's in Vegas?  You think she's waiting for us with tassles on her titties?  Vegas is too crass for Betty.
I said, 'No.'  N-O.
Charlie turns to a passage and reads aloud.

"When I grow up I'm going to become a nurse or a veterinarian.  I always want to help people and value all life, be it animal, plant or mineral..." (to Wesley) Does that sound like a goddamn showgirl to you?
Do you hear yourself right now...?  Like a fucking madman...
Wesley drives on stoically.  The Exit comes and goes.
Every American should see the Grand Canyon.  Are you an American?
Yes, I am and we're not going.  Act professional.

Charlie stares at him, hate rising from just below the surface.  He draws a nickel-plated pistol and points it a Wesley's head.  Wesley looks at it and keeps on driving. Charlie knows this isn't the way to handle it.  He lowers pistol.
If you don't take the next turn for the canyon, I'm blowing my goddamn brains all over this car.

He puts the pistol in his mouth and cocks it.  Wesley loo over, not so sure this time. LONG SHOT of the black Town Car as the turn signal comes and it eases onto a lonely dirt road.  Their headlights p out a sign that says: "Grand Canyon Fire Trail.  Forestry Personnel Only."
Rosa and Betty approach the hotel entrance.  Ahead of the black Lincoln Town Car pulls up. Headlights glint on the chrome, hitting Betty in the eye. She freezes, and Rosa b into her.
Sorry.
Betty stares at the car, unable to remember what it shoul mean.  Then a MAN in a tuxedo gets out.  Betty moves on.

A sign on an easel reads "Save the Children."  Betty and present their tickets at the door to a ballroom. Several times there is a stir near the entrance and a scattering of flashbulbs.  Rosa scans the crowd.
Looking for someone?
You never know who you'll see.

Rosa keeps looking.  Finally, GEORGE McCORD - the actor w plays DAVID RAVELL - enters. He comes in with LYLA BRANCH, late 40's, and TWO OTHER ME Several women approach George, some starry-eyed, for quic polite greetings.  He's doing his job of being a soap sta Rosa waits for an opening, then puts her hands on Betty's shoulders and points her at George. ROSA (cont'd) Look who's here!
Betty's jaw drops.  She freezes. ROSA (cont'd) What are you waiting for?   Talk to him! You came fifteen hundred miles for this.

Rosa prods her, then Betty makes her way unsteadily towar George.  When she's a few feet away he looks up. He can't help but notice her - she's beautiful.  She's al looking right into his eyes.  The conversation stops as h does a double take in Betty's direction.
Do I know you from...?
His friends watch as George studies her face.
...of course you do. (hurt) You don't remember me?
I take it I should.  I'm sorry.
We were engaged.
Oh good, another one...
George's friends look at each other.  A few heads turn.
I beg your pardon?

But I'm the one who's sorry.  Letting you go was the biggest mistake of my life. (to his friends) We were thirteen days away from getting married and ... I just got scared. It's a mistake I've had to live with for six years.  But it's behind me now... (to George) And I hope you can put it behind you. I've missed you... David.
George sighs with relief.  His friends smile.  The tensio evaporates.  They can handle a fanatical fan.
That's very kind of you.

The day I left you I just drove and drove.  I drove all day and all that night, and I didn't go anywhere.  I just kept driving.  I stopped at a little country church, and the pastor let me in, and I sat--
... in the very first pew, where we would have sat on our wedding day.

Betty looks at her.  So does George. LYLA (cont'd) I can't believe I remembered that, although I suppose I should.  I wrote it... (to Betty) But that was seven years ago, and you're quoting it verbatim.  I'm flattered... I think.  Or frightened.   What's your name?
Betty Sizemore.  What do you mean you wrote it?
I'm Lyla Branch.  I'm the Producer.
They shake hands.  ACROSS THE ROOM Rosa watches expectant LYLA (cont'd) Alright, I admit it, you had me there. You're better than most of them, anyway...do you have a headshot?
No, wait...what happened next, Betty?
Are you sure you want to encourage this? (BEAT) No, you're right, let's have some fun. So, what did happened next, "Betty"?
Well, David moved out here and started his residency.  Then he met Leslie--
No, no, no.  We know all that.  What happened with you?
I married a car salesman.
The friends laugh.  Rosa watches, confused.  So is Betty.
You were dumped for a car salesman, George!
Why are you calling him George?
Yeah - David - tell us about this car salesman.
George likes the challenge. This party isn't so boring af all.
Oh, you mean Fred.
No, Del.
Right, Del.  Del was one hot salesman. Of cars.  He could talk anyone into anything.
You knew Del?!

Honey, I didn't want to tell you at the time, but Del and I go way back.  We went to school together.  In fact, he saved my life.  Two more minutes in that icy water and I would have drowned.  But Del jumped in and grabbed me.  We fell out of touch eventually, but I still owe him one.
He never told me anything about...that's unbelievable!
Funny, that's just what I was thinking...
I can't tell you how much it hurts me to hear that you married him.
His friends snicker.  Rosa stares.  Betty is oblivious to everything but George.
I'm so sorry.  Life makes us do awful things sometimes.
She's ready to cry.  Which only inspires him all the more
I tried to tell myself it was for the best, that there was a reason behind it. But... Del?
There was no plan!  I was just young and stupid and scared!
You never gave us a chance...
I know that.  I can't tell you how many times I've said that to myself in those exact words.
Betty wipes her tears away as they flow freely now.  Geor doesn't like seeing her cry; he tries to say something bu his friends interrupt.
Hey, don't... come on, I was just... you're not really crying, are you?...  I was just playing along...
Now, look what you've done, George.
Why do they keep calling you George?
I don't know.  Why do you keep calling me George?
Listen - David - It's getting late.
George hesitates; Lyla sees it.
(to Betty) Right, uhh...I feel terrible about this, we have a prior engagement at another party. (BEAT) But... I'd be honored if you'd come.
Yeah, bring your friend along. I'm sure you got a lot of catching up to do...
Rosa watches, stunned, as Betty waves to her as she leave arm-in-arm with the man of her dreams.
The Town Car is parked near one of the viewing stops at t rim.  Charlie stands in the darkness, but Wesley stays in car.
You don't know what you're missing, asshole.
Charlie walks toward the canyon rim.  Suddenly, Betty app in the headlights standing at the rail - her back to Char with a bouquet of flowers.
Just as he closes his eyes to rest, the CAR PHONE RINGS.
Yeah?
Mr. Campbell?
Huh?
Is this Neighborly Life Insurance?
(recovering) Oh, umm, yes, this is Dwight Campbell.
It's Sue Ann Rogers, Betty Sizemore's friend?  I heard from her.

walking toward the rail.  As he nears her, they kiss. Suddenly, REPEATED BLASTS from the car horn. The image of Betty shudders, then blurs, then fades away entirely.  Charlie rubs at his eyes tiredly, then slowly trudges back toward the car. Charlie returns and gets into the car.  Silence.  Wesley stares at him.
... you have a good time?  You make a little wish?
Silence from Charlie. WESLEY (cont'd) Well, guess what?  I found Betty... where she's been, anyway.
Where?  Where is she?
I'm not telling.
What?
I'm not telling 'til you straighten up. You been acting like fucking Jerry Lewis on me and this shit's gotta stop or you can forget about your Betty... I mean it.
A slow transformation comes over Charlie.
Wesley, I'm fine... just tell me where she is.
George, Betty, Lyla and the two friends are waiting outsi the hotel for their cars.
I bought a car from Del, too. He sold me a lemon.
Really?  I put a hundred and thirty thousand miles on mine.
Huh. I had no idea our little lot was so popular...
I never bought a car from Del.  But I loved him.  In my own way.
I guess we all did. (to Betty) You know, I didn't marry Leslie because I loved her.  I married her to forget you...
Oh, David...I'm sorry I caused you that much pain.
A black jeep 4x4 pulls up and ERIC AUGUSTINO, the actor w plays LONNIE, gets out. BETTY (cont'd) Oh my God!  What's Lonnie doing here?
You're late, Eric.
I know.  Why are you guys leaving?
We did our twenty minutes.
Before Eric can take another step Betty SLAPS him across face.  FLASHBULBS go off as PHOTOGRAPHERS capture the mom
You bastard!  How can you even show your face around here?  Do you think we're not onto you?
Who the hell is this?
Sorry.  She thinks you're someone else.
George hustles Betty to his car as photographers continue shoot.
I know exactly who you are!
The Lincoln Town Car rumbles into the dusty parking lot a parks.
This doesn't look like the kind of place Betty would go to.
Maybe she had to use the bathroom.  She pees, doesn't she?!...
Wesley tears the photo of Betty from the glove box.
Be careful with that!
Charlie takes it back and gingerly secures the tape.
Merle is at the bar, drunk, the only customer on a slow night.  Ellen drops two coasters in front of Charlie and Wesley as they sit down.
What can I get you?
We're Federal Marshals, ma'am.
Ellen looks dubiously at their unshaven faces and rumpled clothes.
We're looking for this young lady.

He slides the photo of Betty across the bar. Ellen's gaze drops to the picture for a second, and Charlie sees what was looking for - a flicker of recognition.  He allows himself a satisfied grin. Wesley shows Ellen his badge as Merle checks out the phot
I haven't seen her.
Sure you have!  That's ...
Shut up, Merle.
Charlie continues to grin at Ellen ...
Ma'am, if you've seen this woman--
Betty!  That's her name - Betty.
Charlie takes the photo and puts it back in his pocket.
I never saw that woman before, and neither has Merle.  He drinks too much. And don't try to tell me you're cops.  I
was married to a cop for nine years, and you're not cops.  Now get out of here.

Wesley steps behind Merle, takes a handful of his hair an SLAMS his head into the popcorn machine on the bar.  Merl staggers away, stunned. Wesley removes the tin popcorn sc from a nearby hook. Ellen reaches for something under the bar, but Charlie's faster.  He pins her arm with one hand.
You haven't been very forthcoming with us.

They watch Wesley follow Merle at a slow walk around the table, CLOBBERING him over the head about every five step with the popcorn scoop. Merle wobbles with every shot, but won't go down.  They b a torturous second lap around the table, punctuated by th CLANG of the scoop against Merle's head.
What's your name, dear?
Ellen.
That's a nice name.
After one more CLANGING shot Merle staggers, then falls. Wesley walks over to Charlie and Ellen, drawing his knife
That's a really nice name...
George and Betty are alone.
Lyla's very nice.
Yes, she is.
She told me I was charming and relentless, and would go far in this town.  And she said that unlike the other charming, relentless people she knew, she liked me.
She's a good person to know. (BEAT) So where did you study again?
Carleton School of Nursing.  Two semesters, but Del made me give it up...
Alright, okay... I think you broke the record for staying in character about three hours ago.
You told me that two hours ago.
He pulls up in front of Rosa's apartment and parks. BETTY (cont'd) I haven't been this happy since I was twelve years old.
What happened when you were twelve?

For Mother's Day, I used all my allowance that I'd been saving to take my mother to Kansas City.  We got our nails done and had lunch at "Skies," a restaurant at the top of a building from where you can see the whole city.  It was the last outing we took together.  She died the following year.
Wow ... You just gave me goosebumps, you know that?  You make it all sound so real.  Great improv...
I just want everything to be perfect between us.
I know. Listen, we need to take a time out here.  Can we talk seriously for a minute?
Of course.
At last!  I know how much you want this. You're gifted and extremely determined, but ... it's not up to me.
I know. It's up to us.

Betty leans over and kisses George - so deeply that he's surprised to react. She pulls away abruptly and gets out. BETTY (cont'd) I love you, David.  And I want to see you tomorrow, and the next day, and the next day.
Still surprised, and now a little intrigued, he watches h go inside.
Betty comes in and pours a drink from the fridge. Rosa appears in a nightshirt behind her, framed in the doorway
Were you with him this whole time?
Oh, God!  You scared me!  Yes...
You still in love?
Betty nods.
Does he know you think he's real?
He is real.
Uh-huh... So, what'd you talk about?
Oh, my gosh, everything! My trip out here, what we've both been doing, you know...
No, I'm not sure I could begin to imagine... So, where'd you go?
To a party in the Hollywood Hills.
Was it a huge place?  With a view of the whole world?
Yes.  I'd never been in a place like that before.
I have, lots of times.  My mother used to clean them.  I used to piss in their pools.
Rosa gets up and starts for her bedroom.  She stops. ROSA (cont'd) This isn't fair, you know.  Do you always get what you want?
No, almost never.
But, you're in love with someone who doesn't exist.  You come here, you meet this guy, who should laugh in your face, and instead you leave with him! (BEAT) Betty, you are one-of-a-kind...
Rosa goes into her bedroom and closes the door. Betty smi and nods, sipping at her drink as she retires to her room
From his cell Roy Ostrey hears a door open, then the soun approaching footsteps.  It's Ballard.
Elden, let me out of here. Now! This is ridiculous, I need medical attention!
That's a nice name for what you need...
Come on, I have to get this dressing off...it itches!  And what about my fish? Who is taking care of them?
Ballard doesn't say anything. He's very grim, subdued.  R has never seen him like this.
Just shut up a second and listen... That, uh... that bar in Arizona?  Where you said Betty was?
What about it?
Any idea where it is?
Little place called "Williams," why?
I just got something off the wire. The woman who owns it was murdered last night. (BEAT) Now, I'm not saying I agree with you or nothing, but... what else do you know?
I know plenty.
Palatial, spartan.  Lyla is sitting in the inner court of Lloyd Wright home with George at one knee.
She makes me stretch!  I got inside my character last night like I haven't done in six years on "Reason".  It was a totally rejuvenating experience.
I know, George, I was there.  I'm not denying that she's good.
She's even taken a job as a nurse! (BEAT) David Ravell's getting boring, Lyla.
We know that...
Can I have an evil twin?
No, George, we've already done that with Lonnie.  The blind one last year, remember?
Oh, of course.  Who can forget the Emmy? (BEAT) Then let me bring Betty to the set and see what happens.
I don't know, George...
I'll tell the cast ahead of time. What do you say?
I'll think about it.
It'll be like live television!  Let's live on the edge a little.  You and I can break the mold here!
I said I'll think about it.
Fine, but promise me one thing.  If we use her, I want to direct those episodes. She's my discovery.
Actually, she was my discovery... just like you.
Hmm?
"Would you like ground pepper on that salad, Ms. Branch?"  Remember?
... yeah.

The black Lincoln Town car hurdles along the 10 Freeway, revitalized Charlie back at the wheel.  Surrounded by traffic, the lights of the city in the distance, the two push on toward their new destination.
The black Lincoln Town Car - now washed and gleaming - is parked in front of a modest motel.
Charlie looks like a new man - showered, clear-eyed and energized - he's at the sink shaving as Wesley watches fr his seat on the edge of the bathtub.
So you believed the bartender.  Why?
Well... I think I saw her soul.
That's good.  You're learning.  But let me tell you why I know she was lying. (BEAT) First off, Betty would never fall for a soap star.  It's beneath her.
I dunno, that lady sounded pretty sure...
No, no, Betty came here strictly for business, 'cause it's the biggest market for what she's selling.  I should have known it all along.  I'm kicking myself as I shave here.  So, first thing we...
Wait, wait, wait a minute... that doesn't make sense.
What doesn't?
You gimme this bullshit Psychic Friends theory, you believe that dumbshit trucker, you believe this woman...
I never said that I believed...
No, you believed her, we drove all the way to L.A. so that means you trusted her that much... so why's the rest of her story suddenly so kooky?  Huh?
'Cause I just don't buy it.  Call it instinct.  Call it 35 years of professional know-how...
I call it 'nutty' as my shit after I eat Almond Roca...
You need to remember who you're talking to...
I need to get my goddamn head examined. (BEAT) You can't rule something out on a whim. Or because she's cute.  I've been following your whims all across the U.S. of A. and now I'm tired!  Me!
